snippet: An Obama administration divided over a prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders swept those issues aside in the rush to secure Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
abstract: Interviews reveal that Obama administration was divided over prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders, but swept aside worries in rush to secure Sgt Bowe Bergdahl's release; White House has repeatedly had to defend the deal it cut to bring home the American captive; despite briefing from administration officials, angry lawmakers on both sides of the aisle say they are not convinced that Bergdahl's life was in immediate danger.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT, DAVID E. SANGER and HELENE COOPER
byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger reported from Washington. Helene Cooper reported from Constanta, Romania. Peter Baker contributed reporting from Brussels.

lead_paragraph: An Obama administration divided over a prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders swept those issues aside in the rush to secure Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

headline.seo: Concern for Health of Bowe Bergdahl Drove Prisoner Exchange
headline.main: Behind P.O.W.’s Release: Urgency and Opportunity
headline.print_headline: Behind P.O.W.’s Release: Urgency and Opportunity
